content.question: Sample <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> contains <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> liters of gas at <math alttext="50 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>50</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></math>. Sample <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> contains <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> liter of the same type of gas at <math alttext="20 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The samples are mixed and eventually reach an equilibrium temperature of about <math alttext="40 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following is an accurate description of the process by which the combined sample approaches equilibrium?

choices.label: The molecules of each sample keep moving at the same speeds, and when they are mixed the two speed distributions of the separate samples add together to yield one distribution with a new average speed.
Collisions between molecules of the two samples redistribute the energy so that all the molecules have the same energy.
Every fast molecule from the hotter sample collides with a slow molecule from the cooler sample, transferring energy to the slower molecule.

Collisions occur between molecules of sample <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, between molecules of sample <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and between molecules of samples <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, redistributing energy.

content.answer: Collisions occur between molecules of sample <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, between molecules of sample <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and between molecules of samples <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, redistributing energy.
